reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed this quirky dating sim! I'll break down what I consider to be the pros and cons of the game (seriously though, the pros definitely outweigh the cons.)

Pros:
+ Sometimes visual novels/dating sims suffer from an excess of boring, mononous text. Thankfully, this one does NOT! The writing is fun and engaging, and the scenes aren't unnecessarily long.
+ The characters are unique and pretty realistic, each with their positive and negative traits. I thought they all added flavor to the story.
+ Options for queer romance!!! <3 For my first playthrough, I played as Anne and romanced Isabella... the storyline was simultaneously adorable and sultry.
+ Playing on normal difficulty, the game felt well-balanced. The stats DO matter and you definitely have to think about how you plan your week. The choices make a huge difference too. However, I never felt completely overwhelmed. Basically, the game is not *that* hard, but it isn't a cakewalk, either.
+ The animation is very cute and the game is aesthetically-pleasing overall.
+ Replay value definitely is there, since there are two characters to play and four romance paths for each.

Cons:
- Sometimes that guitar theme song that plays in the background gets really annoying. I think it's a song that's too loud/overwhelming to be playing on loop during some of the scenes.
- I would have liked more art. The only scenes you see drawn out are the two BIG romance scenes you earn (one during spring break and one at the end of the game). There are plenty of other romantic/funny scenes during the game that would have been amazing to actually see instead of just imagine.
- I wish there were more queer romance options (No Anne x Sally!?!?! *pouts*)

If you like dating sims, I encourage you to give this game a whirl! It is sure to entertain!

reviewText:
As a visual novel dating simulation with a $25.00 price tag, Roommates had high expectations to live up to when I started it. There are definitely a couple of things it does right: the diversity of the cast of characters (in terms of ethnicity, sexual orientation, and gender) is well done. It's also nice to see a dating game where players have a choice between playing as a male or female protagonist (each of which can romance both male and female love interests).
However, I found it to be severely lacking for the following reasons:

- I only found two of the characters (Dominic and Isabella) worth pursuing. The others were either boring or downright unappealing to me (particularly Rakesh, who constantly seemed out to get the straight-laced protagonist in trouble).

- The male protagonist is so outlandishly obnoxious that after playing as the female main character (during which you're able to romance him), I had absolutely no interest in playing as him.

- The romances end with the characters going their separate ways. The only way to get a happy ending is to achieve a set of frustratingly hidden goals in addition to successfully wooing your character of choice. This was intriguingly realistic, but also severely disappointing.

I found myself losing interest in it after completing only a couple of playthroughs and then struggling my way (via a guide) to one of the happy endings. The thought of going back to play it again fills me with a sense of exhausted boredom—which is exactly how you shouldn't feel when you're thinking about a good dating sim.

reviewText:
Roommates is a dating sim/visual novel where you play as either a guy or a girl who starts at college. Like other games in the genre you decide for each part of the day what you want to do, which increases or decreases certain statistics.

A great feature in this game is that you can schedule the week planner ahead of time, rather than needing to decide each day (part) again what you want to do next. And you can also change this at any time.

The daily routine is interrupted by events throughout the week, which mainly serve to advance the story and your relationship with the other characters.

The writing is hilarious at points and Roommates has a good rock soundtrack.

Some minor gripes I have are that there is very little animation other than characters sliding in and out, and that it isn't always clear what your chosen response will lead to. At times I picked what I thought was a flirting response only to have my character say something completely inappropriate, destroying their relationship with the character I was pursuing at the time.

Very unique to the genre, Roommates has both girl chasing boy, boy chasing boy, and homosexual relationships included. Because of this there are multiple endings and many choices in this game really matter.

Overall this is a highly impressive VN.

So I just wrote a really big review, but I figured no one would read it and I stutter with words. So I burned that thing. Here I go again.

Roommates!!
What is Roommates? Roommates it's that book you know it's not that good, but you like anyway. It's a mixed bag. A mixed bag of... actually, is more like a cake. A cake filled with good stuff and some bad stuff. I'm having a hard time with this metaphor.

So, what is Roommates? Roommates is a VN with some simulator sim stuff tossed in. You can choose between two characters, sweet and shy Anne or loud and obnoxious Max, and get through college. This means, of course, getting a boy/girlfriend. You'll also have to manage your time to study, get money and raise the correct stats you need for the ending you want.

Okay, okay, now. How well does the game accomplish this little simulation of college? I'm a lazy bum and not in college, so I've no idea. But as a game it's pretty fun. The simulation sim part of it is pretty good and well balanced. Not too hard, not too easy. The characters are actually pretty good, even though first impressions might not say so. Cliche, but well handled and charming. You learn to like them and want to see more of them. There's diversity in them, from beliefs to oriental sexuations (yes). That aside, The game has quite a lot of content and requires at least a few playtroughs to get most of it, quite a lot more to get all the endings. The art and music is okay. Good, but nothing to write home about. The storyline is just kinda there. You're in college, having fun and trying to get laid.

Overall, I found the game really enjoyable. The comedy is good, the characters are fun to read, and you just want to keep moving forward to see more of these fun situations involving them.


So the game is great? Should you run to buy it!?

Errr... not quite? There's some stuff that will put some people off. First, the characters. I liked them all, but some of them are kind of a hit or miss. A lot of people will instantly hate Max, the male protagonist. And the characters are probably the only reason you'd want to keep playing, so not liking them is kind of a big deal. And about the content... while it's true that there's several routes and endings to get, the story is just kinda there and aside from some events there might be little reasons to replay the game. Many players will lose interest after getting one or two endings.

So the game sucks!?
No! Well, I don't think so, anyawy!  I've been charmed by the game. I know the characters have some problems, and I know the writing can be repetitive and uninspired. But honestly, I think the game deserves some playtime, specially if you like visual novels. It's by no means a bad game, it simply falls short at the price point is at. My advice is get it during sale. You probably won't get every ending, but you'll get some enjoyment out of it!

reviewText:
Roommates is the latest dating sim by Winter Wolves.  Basically, you take on the role of either Max or Anne and play through their first year of university, possibly romancing one of their roommates in the process.  Without a doubt, it's definitely one of the longest dating sims I have yet to play and as others have mentioned, it is the best one that Winter Wolves has released up to now and I do agree with that opinion.

I like that you can play as either a guy or a girl, a feature that isn't found in many dating sims.  Although most of the relationships are GxB or BxG, there is a GxG and a BxB one so there is a nice variety.  The art is quite good as well and the tutorial near the beginning gives a nice and brief explanation as to how the stats work.

Now despite that I did like the game, I should point out the flaws.  First, I noticed that there were some typos and grammar errors.  They were more obvious when you play as Max but I do think that these mistakes could have been ironed out better.  Occasionally, there were inconsistencies between the writing and the art so those could have been smoothed out better, too.  In addition, there were some bugs.  Fortunately, they didn't make the game crash but they were obvious when some red text would appear.  Basically, certain facial expressions that should have appeared didn't.  These are minor bugs, of course, but still, they should have been addressed before the release of the game.

Finally, here is the one thing that did bother me although I know that others will be perfectly fine with it.  Although the art is beautiful, I didn't like how the females were portrayed as pin-up models or Barbie dolls.  (I'd go into detail about that but I think most people will get the idea of what I'm talking about.)  I do understand that it is a game but even in games (or any fictional work), I do like females to be portrayed somewhat realistically and let's just say that a lot of females do not look like the ones in Roommates.  lol

Overall, though, I did like the game, so much so that I wanted to go through all the paths and get all the achievements and what not.  I'd recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of dating sims, as there's surely a lot of replay value.  That alone would make this game worth buying.

Nothing too deep or special, but it is good, simple fun.
Takes a couple of hours to complete the game and has quite some replayability (as there are multiple endings). Though your first playthrough will probably remain the 'best', as it is your first encounter with the game and everything is still new and exciting.

- You want a VN with multiple endings (that are actually worth checking out).
- You like a dating sim / a story that revolves around college.

The only thing that annoyed me quite a bit was the (repetitive) rock music. Some tracks were spot-on, whilst other tracks really kind of ruined the mood in some scenes ... But you get used to it fast enough and the overall experience is still really nice. So if you answered yes to the (most) questions above, just get the game ^^ (might wanna get it during a sale as the game is indeed rather expensive :p).

reviewText:
9/10

I only played through Anne's perspective and went after Max so keep that in mind.

Game Visual Quality:
Overall this game is actually a very good dating sim. Coming from past Winter Wolves games, this is a huge step up in quality. While there is still grinding in terms of getting stats up to get the special ending as per all games made by this company, the quality of this game is much higher and very polished. The UI looks better and the music sounds better as well.

Premise
You're moving into a living area and are seeking personal growth. For Anne this is trying to be more social after living a sheltered life. You have 21 weeks to get two stats up to a total of over 600 to get the good ending.

Con
This is my one complaint about the game and why I won't be replaying it to get the other endings. Even on easy mode you need to have good management of what you're doing week to week. To be honest, I can see making it hard onr hard or normal mode so you actually have to try on your first playthrough. But to still have it be a large in factor in easy mode when you're just trying to see the other endings is just annoying. Though honestly, this is my only problem with the game and I might return to play through other endings one day.

Solution
In the game a very underlooked at attribute is your energy, if it falls below 70% you have more of a chance of failing at activities so it's important you keep that up. This means sleeping in and taking naps and going to bed early a lot. Also it's amusing to note that studying on your own gives you a higher booste to grades than attending class... Reminds me of actual college. So as long as you keep your energy up you should be able to exceed the 600 points required but mind you I did this on easy mode, you might just make it on normal. This does feel like it needs rebalancing to be honest to be less grindy feeling but not that much extra effort.

Pros
Now for the good in this game, for once in a dating sim your own character experiences growth! Anne will grow to be more social and Max can be more studious, based on your own decisions while playing as them of course. There is a decently diverse group of people to court and it's really nice that the game includes same gender relationships. It's just something that in this day and age should be more normal in a dating sim.

You'll have a few events during the week that you can either skip and gain energy or play and raise relationships with other characters. Skipping is a good way to regain energy if the event doesn't relate to the character you're trying to woo. Of course at the end if you never help the other characters you won't see what happens to them at the end but hey, they're not the one you're trying to date!

Pros Cont.
Okay one major thing in dating sims is well the lack of taking it all the way in relationships. I mean, I'm not in it for that but still, it makes things feel more real when you sleep with the character you're dating. This game does this right. Mid game if you've wooed your chosen character enough you can sleep with them. Then through the rest of the school year they'll give you small events where it's almost said that you slept together again. reviewText:
Full disclosure, I write this review having only played the AnneXIsabella route.

As far as the actual novel part of this VN is concerned, I recommend it. It's well-written and the characters are diverse and likeable. I think you're gaurenteed to find at least one person you really like and probably at least one you don't. The situations that pop up have a good slice of life feel to them and play off each character well. If I was going to complain about something, I would say that the story seems to lack drama, and doesn't have much of a conflict, if any. The story is really just character growth, which in itself is entertaining, but only if you enjoy reading the characters, and aren't expecting huge plot points to happen. Keep in mind, this might come from having only played one route, as well as playing as politely as possible to avoid conflict. Being difficult to get along with might lead to some more tense interactions.

The game also features a sim element, which determines how well you'll get along with each character. I feel like this system is easily min-maxed, and becomes sort of pointless once you know how to manipulate it. You can only fully develop your relationship with one character per playthrough, meaning you only need to work on the stats related to that character, leaving the others at 0. I managed to find a schedule combination that didn't let my energy drop below 75%, brought in as much money as I was spending, and developed my stats enough that I ended off with ~700 points combined in Isabella's stats. Once I found this combo, I never had to change my schedule, making the entire system pointless. AGAIN, this may only be possible on the Isabella route, but I doubt it. I will say, however, the tiny bits of flavour text that you get while the schedule plays out are great, including, if you're working the cafe, one of my favourite Simpson's quotes.

Technically speaking, the game looks and sounds nice by visual novel standards, and everything runs smoothly.

Overall, I enjoyed my time spent with the novel (it took me about 4.5 hours to go through one route, of which there are 8) and will probably go back and view other character's routes.

Roommates is a decent visual novel that's rough around the edges. The only faults of the game are minor things, but there's a lot of nit-picky things that add up. Here are a few:

-Whenever you gain a relationship boost, it's always just -5 or +5, and it triggers this tune that eventually becomes annoying,
